title: Lesson 58 – Have Someone do Something; Magpa- and Pa-...-in Verbs

vocabulary.english: AF verb affix that means “to have someone do something”; used with AF roots
A2F verb affix that means “to have someone do something”; used with -um- and ma- roots

contents.markdown: Verbs that have the nuance “to have/make/let someone do something” are called “indirect action verbs”. Sentences formed with these verbs can have two actors: a primary actor (actor) and a secondary actor (A2). The actor has/makes/lets the A2 do something.

There are many indirect action verb affixes, but this lesson will only cover _magpa_- and _pa-...-in_. _Magpa_- is the only affix that forms AF indirect action verbs, and can be used with all AF verb roots. _Pa-...-in_ is the most frequently used of three affixes which are used to form A2F indirect action verbs, and can be used with -_um_- and _ma_- verb roots.
<u>Traits of Magpa- Verbs</u>
They perform an AF action.
They add the nuance of “to have/make/let someone do something”.
Used with all AF verb roots.
<u>Magpa- Verb Infinitives </u>
To form the infinitive, add _magpa_ to the root of an AF verb (_mag-, -um-_, etc.).
Ex: magpa + root of gumawâ = magpa + gawâ = magpagawâ = to have someone do something
Ex: magpa + root of lumakí = magpa + lakí = magpalakí = to have someone raise/increase
Ex: magpa + root of pumuntá = magpa + puntá = magpapuntá = to have someone go
<u>Magpa- Verb Aspects</u>
_Magpa_- verbs aspects are formed as shown. Notice that it is similar to _mag_- verb aspect formation, with the _pa_ of _magpa_ getting repeated in uncompleted and contemplated aspects.
<u>Magpa- Sentences</u>
Magpa Sentence = \*\*Verb\*\*+ actor + object (+ A2) + X

\*\*Notes: The _Magpa_ Sentence is just an AF Standard Sentence with an optional A2. The actor takes _ang_ form, the object takes _ng_ form and X takes _sa_ form. The A2 takes _sa_ form with some exceptions.\*\*

item.english: Jason had a house made. No A2 required.

item.tagalog: Nagpagawa si Jason ng bahay kay David. =
item.english: Jason had David make a house. A2 required.
Raise a dog. (lit Have a dog grow up.) No A2 required.

item.tagalog: Magpalaki ka ng aso sa breeder.
item.english: Have the breeder raise a dog. A2 required.

item.tagalog: Magpapapunta ako ng sasakyan sa Maynila.
item.english: I will have a car go to Manila. Note that there is no A2; Manila is just a directional complement.

contents.markdown: With the root _kain_, it is possible to have A2 take ng form, but it changes the meaning:
<u>Traits of Pa-...-in Verbs</u>
They perform an A2F action.
They add the nuance of “to have/make/let someone do something”.
Used with -_um_- and AF _ma_- verb roots.
<u>Pa-...-in Verb Infinitives </u>

To form the infinitive, add _pa_ before and _in_(_hin_ if it ends in a vowel – see _in_ verbs for other spelling exceptions) after the root of an -_um_- or _ma_- AF verb. Shift the stress to the next vowel.
Ex: pa + root of gumawâ + in = pa + gawâ + in = pagawaín = to have someone do something
Ex: pa + root of matulog + in = pa + tulog + in = patulugin = to have someone sleep
Ex: pa + root of pumuntá + in = pa + puntá + hin = papuntahín = to have someone go
<u>Pa-...-in Completed Aspect</u>
Add _pina_ before the root.
<u>Pa-...-in Uncompleted Aspect</u>
Add _pinapa_ before the root. Note that if the root is stressed on the last vowel the first a in _pinapa_ is stressed too.
Optionally, you can duplicate the first syllable of the root in the completed form.
Ex: pinagawâ => pinágagawâ
Ex: pinatulog => pinatutulog
Ex: pinapuntá => pinápupuntá
But this is less common, so we will not use it from here on.
<u>Pa-...-in Contemplated Aspect</u>
Add _pa_ before the infinitive. Note that if the root is stressed on the last vowel the _a_ in _pa_ is stressed too.
Optionally, you can duplicate the first syllable of the root in the infinitive form.
Ex: pagawain => págagawaín
Ex: patulugin => patutulugin
Ex: papuntahín => pápupuntahín
But this is less common, so we will not use it from here on.
<u>Pa-...-in Sentences</u>
Pa...in Sentence = **Verb** + actor + A2 + object + X
\*\*Notes: The actor takes _ng_ form, the A2 takes _ang_ form, the object takes _ng_ form and X takes _sa_ form.\*\*

item.tagalog: Pinagawa ni Joshua si David ng bahay.
item.english: Joshua had David make a house.
Have the children go to sleep.

item.tagalog: Papupuntahin ko ang asawa ko sa Maynila.
item.english: I will have my wife go to Manila.

exampleSentences.tagalog: Bawal siyang magpagawa ng halo-halo sa mga bata.
exampleSentences.english: He is not allowed to have the children make halo-halo.

exampleSentences.tagalog: Para kanino pinatulog ni Joshua ang mga estudyante?
exampleSentences.english: Who did Joshua have the students go to sleep for?

exampleSentences.tagalog: Bakit niya siya pinapapunta sa tindahan tuwing Linggo ng hapon?
exampleSentences.english: Why does he have her go to the store every Sunday afternoon?

exampleSentences.tagalog: Nakanino ang gurong magpapalaki ng mga mangga?
exampleSentences.english: At whose place will the teacher have mangos grown?

exampleSentences.tagalog: Ayaw pagawain ni Mrs. Cruz ang mga babae ng lechon.
exampleSentences.english: Mrs. Cruz does not like to have the women make lechon.

exampleSentences.tagalog: Gaano siya kabilis nagpapunta ng sasakyan sa kanila?
exampleSentences.english: How fast did she have a car go to their place? (kanila)

exampleSentences.tagalog: Kumusta ang pinapatulog ni Jasmine ngayon?
exampleSentences.english: How is the one Jasmine is putting to sleep now?

exampleSentences.tagalog: Paano ka magpapagawa ng mga inumin kina Luis at Diego?
exampleSentences.english: How will you get Luis and Diego to make drinks?

exampleSentences.tagalog: Puwede ba kayong magpalaki ng manok sa bahay mo?
exampleSentences.english: Can you (pl.) raise a chicken at your house?

exampleSentences.tagalog: Pinagawa ko ng halo-halo ang mga pinagsandukan ko ng adobo.
exampleSentences.english: I had the ones I scooped adobo for make the halo-halo.
